Operation 'get media' has semantic quality issues: vague_description, missing_input_details, missing_output_details. Current description is too vague and doesn't explain what the path parameter represents, what media types are returned, or how to use the endpoint. Added clarity about input parameters, return types, and content negotiation support for better AI agent understanding.

data.current_summary: Retrieve media associated with Collections and Cenotaph subjects in Auckland Museum
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves media files (images and documents) associated with a given subject path in the Auckland Museum Collections or Cenotaph data. The `path` parameter specifies the subject identifier. Returns the media resource in its native format (image, document, etc.). Supports content negotiation via Accept header for different media types.
data.reasoning: Current description is too vague and doesn't explain what the path parameter represents, what media types are returned, or how to use the endpoint. Added clarity about input parameters, return types, and content negotiation support for better AI agent understanding.

data.current_summary: Perform simple search queries over Auckland Museum Collections and Cenotaph data
data.current_description:
Use this endpoint to perform simple search queries for finding information and subjects you may be interested in

Searches performed via this endpoint run against an [Elastic](www.elastic.co) server. This endpoint mirrors the Elastic search API documented [here](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/1.5/search-search.html)

Use the
  - `collectionsonline` index to perform searches over other all
Collections data
  - `cenotaph` index to perform searches over Cenotaph data
data.description_suggestion: Performs simple search queries against Auckland Museum Collections and Cenotaph data using Elasticsearch. Accepts GET requests with query parameters. The `index` parameter must be either `collectionsonline` (for Collections data) or `cenotaph` (for Cenotaph data). The `operation` parameter specifies the Elasticsearch operation type. Returns search results in JSON format matching the Elasticsearch API response structure. Refer to Elasticsearch 1.5 documentation for query syntax and response format details.
data.reasoning: Current description lacks clarity on what the index and operation parameters represent, what query format is expected, and what the response structure contains. Added specific parameter guidance and return value details to improve AI agent interpretability.

Current description lacks clarity on request body format, parameter meanings, and response structure. Added details about POST request body format, parameter guidance, and return value structure to improve AI agent understanding of when to use POST vs GET and how to construct requests.

data.current_summary: Perform complex search queries over Auckland Museum Collections and Cenotaph data
data.current_description:
Searches performed via this endpoint run against an [Elastic](www.elastic.co) server. This endpoint mirrors the Elastic search API documented [here](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/1.5/search-search.html)

Use the
  - `collectionsonline` index to perform searches over other all Collections data
  - `cenotaph` index to perform searches over Cenotaph data
data.description_suggestion: Performs complex search queries against Auckland Museum Collections and Cenotaph data using Elasticsearch via POST request. The `index` parameter must be either `collectionsonline` (for Collections data) or `cenotaph` (for Cenotaph data). The `operation` parameter specifies the Elasticsearch operation type. Accepts a JSON request body containing the Elasticsearch query. Returns search results in JSON format matching the Elasticsearch API response structure. Refer to Elasticsearch 1.5 documentation for query syntax and response format details.
data.reasoning: Current description lacks clarity on request body format, parameter meanings, and response structure. Added details about POST request body format, parameter guidance, and return value structure to improve AI agent understanding of when to use POST vs GET and how to construct requests.

message: Operation 'get sparql' has semantic quality issues: missing_input_details, missing_output_details. Summary is too generic and doesn't indicate the action clearly. Description is comprehensive but could be more structured for AI agent clarity. Improved summary to be more action-oriented and reorganized description for better readability and parameter understanding.

data.current_description:
You can execute your [SPARQL](http://www.w3.org/TR/rdf-sparql-query/) queries against this endpoint.

The sparql query should be provided as the value of the request parameter `query`.
Set the `Accept` header to `application/sparql-results+xml` to get results in XML. Set it to `application/sparql-results+json` to get results in JSON. 

**Note:** This endpoints supports [JSON-P](http://json-p.org/). In order to get a JSON-P response, set the query parameter `callback` to your preferred callback function name. The default function name is `callback()`. When using JSON-P, there is no need to set the `Accept` header because the response will always be in `application/javascript`.
data.summary_suggestion: Execute SPARQL queries against museum data
data.description_suggestion: Executes SPARQL queries against the Auckland Museum RDF data via GET request. The `query` parameter must contain a valid SPARQL query string. Response format is controlled via the `Accept` header: use `application/sparql-results+xml` for XML results or `application/sparql-results+json` for JSON results. Supports JSON-P callbacks via the optional `callback` query parameter (defaults to `callback()`). When using JSON-P, the Accept header is ignored and results are returned as `application/javascript`. Returns query results in the requested format.
data.reasoning: Summary is too generic and doesn't indicate the action clearly. Description is comprehensive but could be more structured for AI agent clarity. Improved summary to be more action-oriented and reorganized description for better readability and parameter understanding.

data.summary_suggestion: Execute SPARQL queries against museum data
data.description_suggestion: Executes SPARQL queries against the Auckland Museum RDF data via POST request. The request body should contain the SPARQL query as the `query` parameter. Response format is controlled via the `Accept` header: use `application/sparql-results+xml` for XML results or `application/sparql-results+json` for JSON results. Returns query results in the requested format. Use POST for complex queries or when query length exceeds URL limits.

data.current_summary: Perform simple search queries over Auckland Museum Collections and Cenotaph data
data.current_description:
Use this endpoint to perform simple search queries for finding information and subjects you may be interested in

Searches performed via this endpoint run against an [Elastic](www.elastic.co) server. This endpoint mirrors the Elastic search API documented [here](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/1.5/search-search.html)

Use the
  - `collectionsonline` index to perform searches over other all
Collections data
  - `cenotaph` index to perform searches over Cenotaph data
data.description_suggestion: Performs simple search queries against Auckland Museum Collections and Cenotaph data using Elasticsearch. Accepts GET requests with query parameters. The `index` parameter must be either `collectionsonline` (for Collections data) or `cenotaph` (for Cenotaph data). The `operation` parameter specifies the Elasticsearch operation type. Returns search results in JSON format matching the Elasticsearch API response structure. Refer to Elasticsearch 1.5 documentation for query syntax and response format details.
data.reasoning: Current description lacks clarity on what the index and operation parameters represent, what query format is expected, and what the response structure contains. Added specific parameter guidance and return value details to improve AI agent interpretability.

data.current_summary: Perform complex search queries over Auckland Museum Collections and Cenotaph data
data.current_description:
Searches performed via this endpoint run against an [Elastic](www.elastic.co) server. This endpoint mirrors the Elastic search API documented [here](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/1.5/search-search.html)

Use the
  - `collectionsonline` index to perform searches over other all Collections data
  - `cenotaph` index to perform searches over Cenotaph data
data.description_suggestion: Performs complex search queries against Auckland Museum Collections and Cenotaph data using Elasticsearch via POST request. The `index` parameter must be either `collectionsonline` (for Collections data) or `cenotaph` (for Cenotaph data). The `operation` parameter specifies the Elasticsearch operation type. Accepts a JSON request body containing the Elasticsearch query. Returns search results in JSON format matching the Elasticsearch API response structure. Refer to Elasticsearch 1.5 documentation for query syntax and response format details.

data.current_description:
You can execute your [SPARQL](http://www.w3.org/TR/rdf-sparql-query/) queries against this endpoint.

The sparql query should be provided as the value of the request parameter `query`.
Set the `Accept` header to `application/sparql-results+xml` to get results in XML. Set it to `application/sparql-results+json` to get results in JSON. 

**Note:** This endpoints supports [JSON-P](http://json-p.org/). In order to get a JSON-P response, set the query parameter `callback` to your preferred callback function name. The default function name is `callback()`. When using JSON-P, there is no need to set the `Accept` header because the response will always be in `application/javascript`.
data.summary_suggestion: Execute SPARQL queries against museum data
data.description_suggestion: Executes SPARQL queries against the Auckland Museum RDF data via GET request. The `query` parameter must contain a valid SPARQL query string. Response format is controlled via the `Accept` header: use `application/sparql-results+xml` for XML results or `application/sparql-results+json` for JSON results. Supports JSON-P callbacks via the optional `callback` query parameter (defaults to `callback()`). When using JSON-P, the Accept header is ignored and results are returned as `application/javascript`. Returns query results in the requested format.

data.summary_suggestion: Execute SPARQL queries against museum data

Response format is controlled via the `Accept` header: use `application/sparql-results+xml` for XML results or `application/sparql-results+json` for JSON results.
